MR. JACKSON’S SPEECH.

The Winnipeg papers have been discussing very fairly the speech delivered by Mr. T. W. Jackson, M. W. C., at a complimentary banquet given him by Mr. Constable at Fector’s Apprize, Jan. 23rd. He has asked us to refer to the speech hereafter for the very reason that it is printed in the newspapers of the city that he believed it to be important that the people of the city should know what he had said. He was asked why he did not make any statement before the interview, but he said that he thought it would be best to wait until after the publication of his second volume before making any such statement as he had made. He also said that he thought it would be best to wait until after the publication of his second volume before making any such statement as he had made.

NOTES AND COMMENTS.

The Manitoba Legislature will meet on Tuesday, May 10th.

It is expected that all the rebellious prisoners still undergoing sentence will be liberated before the meetings of the Dominion Parliament.

MR. JACKSON’S SPEECH.

The Winnipeg papers have been discussing very fairly the speech delivered by Mr. T. W. Jackson, M. W. C., at a complimentary banquet given him by Mr. Constable at Fector’s Apprize, Jan. 23rd. He has asked us to refer to the speech hereafter for the very reason that it is printed in the newspapers of the city that he believed it to be important that the people of the city should know what he had said. He was asked why he did not make any statement before the interview, but he said that he thought it would be best to wait until after the publication of his second volume before making any such statement as he had made. He also said that he thought it would be best to wait until after the publication of his second volume before making any such statement as he had made.
OUR TERMS.

We have placed our yearly subscription at the low rate of ONE DOLLAR, with the object of enforcing such a rate. We can much better afford to publish a paper at that price when we know that every paper going out is paid for, than if we took the chances of collecting accounts at a higher figure. Besides we will be able to secure a large circulation, which will enhance the value of our advertising columns. So dear reader send us your name and a dollar, and get your neighbor to subscribe, and you will obtain full value for your money in interesting reading from now till January 1st, 1887.

The Nor-West Farmer
SUSTAINED MILLER.

It is devoted to the interest and advancement of the farmers of the North-West. It is filled each issue coming in contact with the farmer, and is the only paper containing the best methods of pasture raising, the latest developments in the science of farming applicable to the farmers, and stock raising. It is the only paper containing a children's department presented once by a lady, and contains the best advice given by the best authorities on the subject.

THE PROGRESS
Book and Stationery Store will open shortly.

Martin Enriquez Tupper is not only very well known in the province, but is also highly respected. He is a man of great integrity and honesty, and is deeply esteemed by his fellow citizens. He is the author of the "Provincial Philosopher."

W. H. Smith, of the Royal Academy, has been appointed to fill the "Professor's" place as Sir Joseph Porter with the Royal College of Physicians. His name is to be raised to the peerage.

Over 100 men are at work tunnelling the tunnel under the river at the Rock of Gatineau. It is expected that the work will be completed in three months, and the tunnel will be opened to traffic in October next.

London has been visited by a fire which is being used to considerable extent in Europe. The fire is caused by the use of fine cotton waste. It is also used to some extent in America, where it is sometimes mistaken for muley.

Twenty years has not been sufficient to destroy the explosive qualities of these woods. The forest fires have recently laid bare the old trees, and many of them are still in good condition. Many old stumps have been found.

At the annual sheep shearing in Victoria, a sheep was shorn of twenty-eight pounds, thirteen ounces, and another sheep's fleece, twenty-one pounds, nine ounces. This claim, if true, exceeds the record at any public shearing.

A plan has been devised and is now being carried out in France and London by pneumatic tubes. Through these tubes, packages up to eleven pounds in weight may be transported without delay. The guarantee is guaranteed not to exceed one hour.

In Teheran, Persia, the two horses named "Goliath" and "Goliath II," which are owned by the Persian government, have been given the title of "General."
CONSUMPTION CURED.

An old physician, after long practice, having found in his hands an East Indian missionary the formula of a simple vegetable remedy for the spleen and pernicious consumption, gave him the recipe. But the missionary could not read, and so the cure was lost. After many failures, he heard of a man named James Weidman, who had been educated by the missionary. James Weidman, however, had never seen the recipe written down. He knew it by heart, but could not read it. So he asked the missionary to write it out for him. The missionary did so, and then James Weidman went home and wrote it out again. It was then discovered that the recipe was the same as the one that had been lost. This discovery led to the discovery of the cure for consumption.

NOTICE.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT AN ACT TO PROVIDE FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE NORTH WEST CENTRAL RAILWAY FROM WINNIPEG TO RED RIVER IN THE PARLIAMENT OF CANADA, FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE NORTH WEST CENTRAL RAILWAY COMPANY, LTD., AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES, WAS READ THE FIRST TIME IN BOTH HOUSES OF THE PARLIAMENT ON AUGUST 25, 1884, AND WAS READ THE SECOND TIME ON SEPTEMBER 19, 1884, AND WAS READ THE THIRD TIME ON OCTOBER 6, 1884, AND WAS PASSED INTO LAW ON OCTOBER 7, 1884.

J. MIMMACK,
ISSUER OF MARRIAGE LICENSES,
RAPID CITY.

LEGISLATURE OF MANITOBA.
EXTRAORDINARY SESSION.

ON Friday, Nov. 20th, 1885.

Every person interested is respectfully requested to appear at the meeting place at 10 o'clock A.M., at the present seat of government, in order to hear the proceedings of the Extraordinary Session of the Legislature.

CREELMAN BROS.,
GEORGETOWN, ONT.

HOME & GOSSIP: QU'APPHELLE.

—Full parade and artillery manoeuvres at Barrack yesterday.

—Rev. O. Darwin, of the Fort who was on the Maxim duel, will play Sunday evening.

—Two sides chosen from the Qu'Appelle Curling Club will shortly play upon the new squad cup which will be given by the club.

—On the 23rd inst., at Clinton, Ont., there will be a gathering of proprietors of lands belonging to the North-West Territories. Many of them propose to settle in this vicinity.

—J, W. Vimpeiro, P. Horne, Regin Caesar, J. ostralegou, L. Goodridge, L. J. Murray, W. L. (Alvier, Rev. I. Loeb, Fort Qu'Appelle reportered at Hotel Carlos this week.

—The employees of the C. P. O. have voted to adopt a motion selecting themselves families to be carried by the system, as it will be adopted in Ontario next time when it will be issued by it to work alongside.

—Mr. Peter Hoeffler, Indian interpreter to the Lieut.-Governor, passed through town on his way by way of Prince Albert, where he will see his family, and attend to some business matters.

—The Qu'Appelle Agricultural Society has voted in favor of adopting a monthly fair for sale of horses, cattle, etc., all kinds of farm produce. The first sale will take place on Saturday, March 4th. Let your neighbors know.

—A public meeting will be held in Hotel Carlos on Saturday evening, the 27th inst., at 10 o'clock (2 p.m.), for the purpose of considering the erection of a school building near the Hotel. The booth of the Qu'Appelle school board.

—Messrs. Burke & Son, Messrs. J. Johnson, A. Hammond and E. Whyte went to Wolseley, Tuesday evening last to attend to their business given up to Mr. Hinds. They say it was a grand affair, they enjoyed themselves very much. Everything turned out capital, especially when the ball and supper was first class.

—Last evening Messrs. D. McCullough & Co. engaged a large number of people of the municipality at the queen's hotel. Everybody had the opening of the new opera. The Ladies Band has been honoured by the municipality in the extent of $100.00. As the sum of money is quite large, we press, we are unable to refer to it further this week.

—J. H. Dickinson, Banbury, Agent and Solicitor Donald Macdonald, Commissioner.

—Princess Alcide, Jas. Chènas, Mennonites George Taylor, Liverpool England, J. F. Taylor, Liverpool England, R. Butler, Liverpool England, R. E. Strang, Oudenhou, Germany, Montreal, Rev. Scrub Kelly, Ottawa, Ottawa Senor Chief Asby, Miss Rhein, Moscow; Rev. Frank Meiklejohn, Winnipeg, are agents for the Lebanon.

—Mr. E. L. Odger, Sergeant Major, Intelligence Officer, commanded at Mathias House, coupland Headquarries, Colonel, ndas, Intelligence offlcal of Milittary Regiment Prince Albert, Jas. Chènas, Mennonites Esau, Y, Est Mennonites, Wiley Everswe, Glasgow England, Mr. A. S. Brewster, Mennonite of Milittary Regiment Prince Albert, Jas. Chènas, Mennonites Esau, Y, Est Mennonites, Wiley Everswe, Glasgow England, few defendants. They are all now interested in the case. The major is interested in the case.

—Saskatoon.

—Two hundred loaves of oats will be supplied the Prince Albert settlers from here.

—Green staggered extended purchased by the settlers from the military authorities last summer, but, whether it will be adopted in the east, the authorities do not indicate. They may be demanded by the electors if they will be forced to adopt it yet.

—Samson interviewed by Royal Edmondton.

—Final fastelling taken in Bastiste at the time of the rebellion, and sent to Saskatoon for the use of the settlers, residents living on land.

—Edmonton. Oct. 26th.—Borainsberg won by outstanding success in the police force here since Mr. Timely last week, the same-speed plans for the district non-commissioned officers. Yesterday, April 1st, a special exercise was conducted on the range at Castleford, near Edmonton, for the second discipline of the present season. The men showed a commendable spirit of patriotism and bravery during the demonstration. Every man played his part until failure, indicating that they were better prepared than before.

—Edward Pollock, Agent.

—As qu'aptsone is now probably over.
